qas.question: What 3 versions of the build did Microsoft first release?

answers.text: standard 32-bit and 64-bit versions, plus a special 64-bit version which included SDKs and developer tools

qas.question: What developer tools did the build have?

answers.text: Visual Studio Express and Expression Blend

qas.question: How many downloads occured in the first 12 hours?
When did the developer preview expire?
When was the Developer preview initially intended to expire?

plausible_answers.text: 32-bit and 64-bit versions, plus a special 64-bit version which included SDKs and developer tools

qas.question: What 4 versions of the build did Microsoft first release?

plausible_answers.text: Visual Studio Express and Expression Blend

qas.question: What developer tools didn't the build have?
How many downloads occured in the first 21 hours?
When didn't the developer preview expire?
When wasn't the Developer preview initially intended to expire?

context: The build was released for download later in the day in <a0_0>standard <b5_0>32-bit and 64-bit versions, plus a special 64-bit version which included SDKs and developer tools<b5_0/><a0_0/> (<a1_0><b6_0>Visual Studio Express and Expression Blend<b6_0/><a1_0/>) for developing Metro-style apps. The Windows Store was announced during the presentation, but was not available in this build. According to Microsoft, there were about <a2_0><b7_0>535,000<b7_0/><a2_0/> downloads of the developer preview within the first 12 hours of its release. Originally set to expire on <a4_0><b9_0>March 11, 2012<b9_0/><a4_0/>, in February 2012 the Developer Preview's expiry date was changed to <a3_0><b8_0>January 15, 2013<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
